statement.tex: %text A cooperative society of farmers has 50 hectares of land to grow two crops A and B. The profits from crops A and B per hectare are estimated as ₹ 10,500 and ₹ 9000 respectively. To control weeds, a liquid herbicide has to be used for crops A and B at the rate of 20 litres and 10 litres per hectare respectively. Further not more than 800 litres of herbicide should be used in order to protect fish and wildlife using a pond which collects drainage from this land. Keeping in mind that the protection and other wildlife is more important than earning profit, how much land should be allocated to each crop so as to maximize the total profit? Form an LPP from the above and solve it graphically. %

\\ %text Given that % \begin{tabular}{|c|c|} \hline \text{Symbol} & \text{Meaning} \\ \hline L_A & \text{Land allocated to crop A} \\ \hline L_B & \text{Land allocated to crop B} \\ \hline \end{tabular}\\ %text \underline\text{is the following correct?} %
\\ %text Does the graph below correctly show the constraints we identified in Step 1 and also the \underline\text{ feasible region and optimal points}? %
\\ \textbf{Right or wrong?} \\ %text Given the constraints, the maximum possible profit will be as follows. %

reason.tex:
%text Begin the problem by collecting all the facts.
\underline{\text{Available land}}\\ We don't have more than 50 hectares of land. Hence, $L_A + L_B \leq 50$.
\underline\text{Herbicide}\\ We would need 20 litres\it{ per hectare} of herbicide for crop A and 10 litres \it{per hectare} for crop B.
Hence, we would need $20L_A + 10L_B$. But we we cannot use more than 800 litres total. So, $20L_A + 10L_B\leq 800 \implies 2L_A + L_B \leq 80.$
\underline\text{Profit}\\ And we must maximize profits. \[ \text{Profit} = \pi = 10,500\cdot L_A + 9,000\cdot L_B \] %

%text If we plot $L_A$ along the x-axis and $L_B$ along the y-axis, then the two lines we need are % \begin{align} L_B &= 80 - 2L_A \\ L_B &= 50 - L_A \end{align} %text
You can confirm that % \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|} \hline a & b & c & d & e \\ \hline (0,80) & (0,50) & (30,20) & (40,0) & (50,0) \\ \hline \end{tabular} \\ %text Moreover, as we have to satisfy both constraints (on land and herbicide use), the feasible region has to \underline\text{below points b,c and d}.
Only points in this region are below \underline\text{both} the lines. %

%text We identified three possible optimal points in Step 2. We now only have to calculate the profit at each of these points and compare. % \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|} \hline \text{Point} & \text{Coordinates }(L_A,L_B) & \text{Profit} \\ \hline b & (0,50) & ₹ 450,000 \\ \hline c & (30,20) & ₹ 495,000 \\ \hline d & (40,0) & ₹ 420,000 \\ \hline \end{tabular} \\ %text It is obvious from the table that with 30 hectares given to crop A and 20 hectares to crop B, our profits will be maximum. %
